Graphical abstract Sulfur-doped VN (S-VN) anchored on N, S-doped multi-dimensional carbon was synthesized and employed as a cathodic catalyst for oxygen reduction reaction in flexible zinc-air batteries, enabling the charging of a smartwatch and a mobile phone. Owing to the distinctive structural characteristics, vanadium nitride (VN) is highly regarded as a catalyst for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in zinc-air batteries (ZABs). However, VN exhibits limited intrinsic ORR activity due to the weak adsorption ability to O-containing species. Here, the S-doped VN anchored on N, S-doped multi-dimensional carbon (S-VN/Co/NS-MC) was constructed using the solvothermal and in-situ doping methods. Incorporating sulfur atoms into VN species alters the electron spin state of vanadium in the S-VN/Co/NS-MC for regulating the adsorption energy of vanadium sites to oxygen molecules. The introduced sulfur atoms polarize the V 3dz 2 electrons, shifting spin-down electrons closer to the Fermi level in the S-VN/Co/NS-MC. Consequently, the introduction of sulfur atoms into VN species enhances the adsorption energy of vanadium sites for oxygen molecules. The *OOH dissociation transitions from being unspontaneous on the VN surface to a spontaneous state on the S-doped VN surface. Then, the ORR barrier on the S-VN/Co/NS-MC surface is reduced. The S-VN/Co/NS-MC demonstrates a higher half-wave potential and limiting current density compared to the VN/Co/N-MC. The S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based liquid ZABs display a power density of 195.7 mW cm−2, a specific capacity of 815.7 mA h g−1, and a cycling stability exceeding 250 h. The S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based flexible ZABs are successfully employed to charge both a smart watch and a mobile phone. This approach holds promise for advancing the commercial utilization of VN-based catalysts in ZABs. Keywords S-doped VN Electronic structures Spin state regulation Oxygen reduction reaction Zinc-air batteries 1 Introduction Zinc-air batteries (ZABs) commonly manifest characteristics such as a high theoretical specific capacity (820 mA h g−1), exceptional safety and minimal environmental impact [1–3]. Consequently, ZABs are found widespread application in energy storage/conversion devices, including hearing aids, robots, electric vehicles, and more [1–3]. According to the reaction mechanism, the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) plays an important role in ZABs at the air cathode [4]. However, the actual specific capacity and energy density of ZABs fall short of their theoretical values due to the sluggish kinetics of ORR, posing a significant constraint on the practical use of ZABs in electronic devices [5,6]. As a result, an increasing number of research achievements are being reported in the development of ORR catalysts characterized by high catalytic activity and stability for ZABs [7,8]. Currently, alongside research on precious metal-based ORR catalysts, there is a growing exploration of transition metal-based materials aimed at extending the global utility of precious metals like platinum and palladium [9,10]. Vanadium nitride (VN) is expected to demonstrate excellent activity in ORR due to the theoretically high conductivity, stability, and corrosion resistance [11–14]. The intrinsic ORR activity of VN is difficult to meet the demand for high-performance ZABs [13,15,16]. Therefore, various modification strategies are adopted to improve insufficient ORR performance of VN-based materials, such as the heteroatomic doping and so on [16,17]. The heteroatom doping (such as S, P, B, F, etc.) can regulate electronic structures of the VN and change the original crystal structure characteristics [17]. In particular, the heteroatom doping can lead to the hybridization of energy levels of VN species, thus regulating V 3d-orbital electronic structures in VN species [18]. The d-band center of vanadium sites and the filling environment of hybridized antibonding orbitals can also be regulated [18]. Subsequently, the electron interaction between oxygen-containing intermediates and the VN surface is modified to enhance ORR activity [19,20]. The electrical conductivity of the VN also can be effectively optimized to ensure the efficient and rapid transfer of electrons on the VN surface [13,20]. The VN exhibits regular atomic and electronic configuration [21]. The d-orbital electrons of vanadium atoms are usually split into two distinct orbitals, including dz 2, dx 2 −y 2 orbitals with higher energy states, and dxy , dxz , dyz orbitals with lower energy states [22]. The electron arrangement and electron occupancy of dz 2 and dx 2 − y 2 orbitals at vanadium sites directly affect the catalytic activity of VN-based catalysts. The dz 2 and dx 2 − y 2 orbitals usually participate in bonding with intermediates (such as oxygen-containing species) to form σ-bonds [22]. The spin states of dz 2 and dx 2 − y 2 are improved by the heteroatom doping. The electron arrangement and electron occupation number of dz 2 orbitals in transition metal vanadium are altered after the changed spin states. Thus, the bonding ability and adsorption behavior can be optimized between vanadium sites and oxygen-containing intermediates [20–22]. The atomic radius of sulfur atom is larger than that of the nitrogen atom. The electronegativity of sulfur atom is smaller than that of nitrogen atom. Thus, the sulfur doping can regulate the electron configuration structure of VN species and the spin electron configuration of vanadium sites in VN species. It can optimize the oxygen adsorption capacity on the VN-based catalyst surface, promote the breaking of O−O bonds, reduce the overpotential of reaction, and ultimately enhance ORR activity [21–23]. Here, the S-doped VN anchored on N, S-doped multi-dimensional carbon (S-VN/Co/NS-MC) was successfully designed using the solvothermal and in-situ doping strategies (Scheme 1 ). To begin, the trioctyl methyl ammonium chloride ((C8H17)3CH3N]Cl) ionic liquid is employed to coordinate with the vanadium source (VO3 +). The trioctyl methyl ammonium chloride containing three long carbon chains can serve to isolate VO3 + ions, thereby preventing the aggregation of vanadium atoms into large VN species during high-temperature pyrolysis. During the solvothermal and vacuum carbonization processes, sulfur atoms are in-situ doped into both the carbon skeleton and VN species. Additionally, the Co2+ source was reduced to form Co nanoparticles. Simultaneously, the Co source catalyzed the carbon source, resulting in the formation of one-dimensional carbon nanotubes. The one-dimensional carbon nanotubes, along with the remaining two-dimensional carbon nanosheets, were co-assembled to create a multi-dimensional carbon structure. The multi-dimensional nanostructures can improve mass transfer rate to enhance the performance of ZABs. Finally, the S-VN/Co/NS-MC not only exhibited excellent ORR activity, but also endowed ZABs energy density with close to the theoretical value and excellent charging-discharge stability. 2 Preparation method The synthesis methods of vanadic polyoxometalate (NaVO3 or V-POM)-based ionic liquid ([(C8H17)3NCH]+-POM) and carbon nitride were referred to our reported work [24]. Firstly, 0.2 g [(C8H17)3NCH]+-POM and 0.2 g carbon nitride were successively dispersed in 20 mL C2H5OH and stirred for 1 h, and labelled as solution A. 0.1 mmol Co(NO3)2·6H2O and 0.1 g thiourea were dissolved in 10 mL C2H5OH and sonicated for 1 h as solution B. Then, the solution B was added into solution A in slow drops. After stirring well, the mixture was transferred to 100 mL Teflon-lined steel autoclave and heated at 100 °C for 24 h. Next, after the solvothermal reaction, the solid powder was collected by centrifugation and washed three times with C2H5OH. The solid powder was dried at 60 °C. The dried solid powder was put into a 5 mL porcelain crucible, then the crucible was placed into the single-mouth quartz tube and sealed. The air in quartz tube was evacuated until vacuum. Finally, the optimal catalyst was obtained through rapid calcined at 900 °C for 15 min, and named the S-VN/CO/NS-MC. Moreover, the contrastive VN/Co/N-MC and S-VN/NS-C and VN/N-C samples were synthesized via the similar manner without thiourea, Co(NO3)2·6H2O, and thiourea/Co(NO3)2·6H2O, respectively. To compare ORR activity of catalysts with different sulfur sources, the sample was also prepared via the similar method using thioacetamide replaced thiourea. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characterization The microstructure and morphology of S-VN/Co/NS-MC were observed with scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM). The S-VN/Co/NS-MC mainly presents the one-dimensional (1D) nanotubes and stacked nanosheets to form the multi-dimensional structure (Fig. 1 a). The multi-dimensional structure can accelerate the O2 transport rate and electron transfer rate to result in improved ORR activity of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC [21]. The nanotubes of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC mainly present the bamboo-like structure (TEM images, Fig. 1b and c). The width of bamboo-like nanotubes is around 10–50 nm. The nanoparticles about 10–50 nm (marked with blue circles in Fig. 1b and c) are anchored at bamboo-like nanotubes. Abundant nanosheet structures with the stacked morphology are also observed around the bamboo-like nanotubes. Plentiful small nanoparticles (marked with orange lines in Fig. 1b and c) are densely loaded on nanosheets. Further, high resolution TEM (HR-TEM, Fig. 1d and e) images are performed to visually observe the particles located on bamboo-like nanotubes and nanosheets, respectively. HR-TEM image of the nanoparticle located on bamboo-like nanotubes (Fig. 1d). The nanoparticle with the clear lattice spacing (approximately 0.205 nm) is identified as the (111) lattice plane of Co nanoparticle [12]. The layer with distinct lattice spacing appears around Co nanoparticle. The lattice spacing of the layer is determined to be about 0.34 nm, corresponding to the graphitic carbon layer [25]. The above results indicate that Co nanoparticles effectively convert the carbon source into bamboo-like nanotubes, and then are anchored at bamboo-like nanotubes. In addition to the regulation of the carbon skeleton structure of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC, Co-related species, including Co nanoparticles, are reported to have a positive effect on the promotion of ORR activity [12,23]. HR-TEM image (Fig. 1e) exhibits small nanoparticles loaded on nanosheets. The lattice spacing of 0.249 nm corresponds to the VN (111) lattice plane, while the lattice spacing of 0.207 nm belongs to the VN (200) lattice plane (Fig. 1e). However, the theoretical lattice spacing of the VN (111) lattice plane is 0.238 nm [26]. Compared to the theoretical value, the lattice spacing of the VN (111) lattice plane in S-VN/Co/NS-MC is enlarged by about 0.011 nm. The larger lattice spacing of the VN (111) lattice plane originates potentially from the change of the lattice spacing of VN species after successful doping of sulfur atoms in S-VN/Co/NS-MC [17,19,20]. After the sulfur atom doping, the changed lattice spacing resulted from the change of the original electronic structure of VN species, being also beneficial to optimize the oxygen adsorption energy on VN species, thereby improving the ORR activity of S-VN/Co/NS-MC [19,20]. Moreover, the lattice spacing of the VN (111) lattice plane presents a slight blurring, which potentially originates from the effect of sulfur atom doping into VN species on the lattice spacing. Scan transmission electron microscopy (STEM, Fig. 1f) image of S-VN/Co/NS-MC displays many granular bright spots and some fuzzy bright speckles. The corresponding element mapping images (Fig. 1g) are utilized to confirm the species matched by the bright spots and speckles, respectively. The Co, S, V, N and C element signals are obvious in S-VN/Co/NS-MC. The Co element signal is almost distributed at granular bright spots, and located at carbon nanotube structures, inferring the presentation of elemental Co nanoparticles within S-VN/Co/NS-MC. The V and N element signals overlap well at fuzzy bright speckles, indicating the formation of VN species. This observation confirms that the nanoparticles dispersed on the nanosheets consist of VN species. Crucially, the S element signal also clearly overlaps with V and N signals, implying the successful incorporation of sulfur atoms into VN species. Furthermore, N and S elements are present in the vicinity of VN species, exhibiting a pronounced overlap with C element signal. This result demonstrates the successful doping of N and S elements into the multi-dimensional carbon structure. The element mapping results align with the speculations drawn from TEM and HR-TEM images, confirming the successful synthesis of S-VN/Co/NS-MC. By comparing TEM and HR-TEM images of different samples, the role of S and Co elements of synthesized samples are further analyzed. The accumulation of small particles is discovered in SEM images of VN/N-C and S-VN/NS-C (Fig. S1a and b). There is also no obvious tubular structure. SEM image of VN/Co/N-MC is like that of S-VN/Co/NS-MC (Fig. S1c). The VN/Co/N-MC exhibits a multi-dimensional skeleton structure like the S-VN/Co/NS-MC. There are no 1D nanotubes in VN/N-C and S-VN/NS-C samples. It more clearly confirms that 1D nanotube structures of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC are derived from carbon sources via the catalysis of Co species. The particulate size of VN/N-C is approximately 5 nm (Fig. S2a). The lattice spacings of 0.239 and 0.206 nm in the VN/N-C are attributed to the VN (111) and (200) lattice planes, respectively (Fig. S2b). The particulate size of the S-VN/NS-C is slightly larger (about 5–10 nm) than that of VN/N-C (Fig. S2c). The lattice spacing of 0.249 nm in the S-VN/NS-C corresponds to the VN (111) lattice plane (Fig. S2d). In comparison to the VN (111) lattice plane in VN/N-C without the S source, the lattice spacing of the VN (111) in both S-VN/NS-C and S-VN/Co/NS-MC is enlarged. The incorporation of sulfur atoms leads to a substantial increase in the original lattice spacing of the VN (111) in the S-VN/Co/NS-MC, attributed to the relatively large atomic radius of sulfur. The VN/Co/N-MC primarily presents 1D bamboo-like nanotubes (Fig. S2e). Nanoparticles are clearly visible within the bamboo-like nanotubes. Based on HR-TEM image (Fig. S2f), the lattice spacing of 0.205 nm can be attributed to the Co (111) lattice plane of Co nanoparticles. Compared with the VN/N-C, the 1D bamboo-like nanotube structures in the VN/Co/N-MC are formed through the catalytic action of Co particles. Based on the element mapping images of VN/N-C and S-VN/NS-C (Fig. S3a and b), the small-size characteristic of VN species is also confirmed. The sulfur elements can be successfully doped into VN species within the S-VN/NS-C. Moreover, the S element signal is like that of V and N element signals, which are uniformly distributed in the S-VN/NS-C. The element mapping images of the VN/Co/N-MC (Fig. S3c) again confirm that the particles are indeed Co nanoparticles. As can be seen from the above analysis, the cobalt source mainly plays the role of converting the carbon source into 1D bamboo-like nanotubes during the synthesis process for S-VN/Co/NS-MC. The morphology of S-VN/Co/NS-MC is not significantly changed after doping S atoms into the VN species and carbon substrate. The crystal structure and component phase of samples were analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectroscopy. The XRD diffraction peak at about 25.6° of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC (Fig. 2 a) corresponds to the (002) structural plane of graphitic carbon (PDF#41-1487) [5]. The diffraction peaks at approximately 37.6°, 43.7°, 63.5°, and 76.2° belong to the (111), (200), (220), and (311) lattice planes of VN (PDF#35-0768), respectively [19]. The remaining peaks correspond to the (111), (200), and (220) lattice planes of Co (PDF#15-0806) at approximately 44.2°, 51.5° and 75.9°, respectively [27,28]. These characteristic peaks above indicate the coexistence of VN species and Co nanoparticles in S-VN/Co/NS-MC. In addition to VN, previous studies have reported that Co-related species can have a positive effect on enhancing ORR activity [12,23]. The S-VN/NS-C presents characteristic peaks of VN species (PDF#35-0768) and graphitic carbon (PDF#41-1487). XRD pattern of VN/Co/N-MC displays characteristic peaks like those of S-VN/Co/NS-MC, demonstrating the co-existence of Co nanoparticles and VN species in VN/Co/N-MC. Raman spectroscopy results were utilized to discuss the graphitization and defect degree of samples. The characteristic peaks at ∼1350 and ∼1580 cm−1 are attributed to the defect component (D band) and graphite layer structure (G band, Fig. 2b), respectively [29]. The intensity ratios (Table S1) of D band to G band (I D/I G) of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC, VN/Co/N-MC and S-VN/NS-C are 1.02, 0.96 and 1.11, respectively. Compared with the VN/Co/N-MC, the I D/I G values of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC and S-VN/NS-C are larger. This deduces that the successful doping of sulfur atoms increases the defect degree of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC and S-VN/NS-C [21,30]. The I D/I G values of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC and VN/Co/N-MC are smaller than that of the S-VN/NS-C, implying that Co nanoparticles increase the graphitization degree of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC and VN/Co/N-MC samples [14,16]. The introduced sulfur atoms and Co species eventually led to the I D/I G of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC close to 1.01. It demonstrates that the content ratio of graphite layer structure to defect component in the S-VN/Co/NS-MC is optimized in a balanced way. The high graphitization facilitates promoting the electron transfer rate during electrocatalytic reactions [4,29]. And the abundant defect components can act as active sites to enhance ORR activity [4,29]. Therefore, the S-VN/Co/NS-MC exhibits superior ORR activity to VN/Co/N-MC and S-VN/NS-C. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) is employed to analyze the chemical surface characteristics of S-VN/Co/NS-MC, VN/Co/N-MC and S-VN/NS-C catalysts. Survey spectra (Fig. S4) display the presence of C, N, V and Co elements in the S-VN/Co/NS-MC. The small peak at approximately 164.0 eV is assigned to the S 2p peak, confirming the successful doping of sulfur atoms in the S-VN/Co/NS-MC. The prominent peaks at approximately 514.1 and 521.5 eV correspond to V 2p 3/2 and V 2p 1/2 in V 2p spectra (Fig. 2c) of S-VN/Co/NS-MC, VN/Co/N-MC and S-VN/NS-C, respectively [30]. The V−N peaks verify the presence of VN species in V 2p spectra of S-VN/Co/NS-MC, VN/Co/N-MC and S-VN/NS-C [31]. The peaks corresponding to V4+ 2p 3/2 and V4+ 2p 1/2 of S-VN/Co/NS-MC, VN/Co/N-MC and S-VN/NS-C are positioned at approximately 514.4 and 521.8 eV, respectively [30,31]. Similarly, the peaks at approximately 516.4 and 523.6 eV are attributed to V5+ 2p 3/2 and V5+ 2p 1/2 species of S-VN/Co/NS-MC, VN/Co/N-MC and S-VN/NS-C. Compared with the VN/Co/N-MC, the V 2p binding energy in S-VN/Co/NS-MC and S-VN/NS-C becomes higher. The doping of S atoms leads to the alteration of the electronic structure of original VN species. This change in turn shifts the binding energy of V element in the S-doped VN [18]. This higher binding energy signifies the modified electron structure of vanadium atoms in S-VN/Co/NS-MC subsequently regulates the adsorption energy of vanadium sites to oxygen molecules [18,32]. Additionally, the presence of V5+ species likely stems from the surface of S-VN/Co/NS-MC, VN/Co/N-MC, and S-VN/NS-C materials, oxidized by exposure to air [9]. The Co−S/V−S bonds are fitted at about 161.5 eV in S 2p XPS spectrum (Fig. 2d) of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC [33]. This suggests that the V−S bond observed in the S 2p XPS spectrum of S-VN/Co/NS-MC probably is attributed to the doping of sulfur atoms into the VN species. This finding aligns with the conclusion drawn from the changes observed in the lattice spacing of VN species in XRD and HR-TEM analyses. Due to the presence of Co nanoparticles in carbon nanotubes of S-VN/Co/NS-MC, the Co−S bond is also possibly caused by the bonding of Co atoms to S atoms of carbon nanotubes, so the presence of Co−Sx sites in S-VN/Co/NS-MC cannot be excluded. Co−Sx sites are reported to be species with a positive boosting effect on ORR activity. The characteristic peaks of C−S−C 2p 3/2 and C−S−C 2p 1/2 are also fitted in S 2p XPS spectra, confirming the successful doping of sulfur atoms into the multi-dimensional carbon skeleton, resulting in the formation of N, S-doped carbon in the S-VN/Co/NS-MC [21]. The four subpeaks in N 1s XPS spectra (Fig. 2e) are matched as metal−N, pyridinic-N, graphitic-N and oxidized-N, respectively [17]. The metal−N is consistent with the fitting results of V−N peaks in the V 2p spectra, further indicating the existence of VN species. Compared with that of VN/Co/N-MC, the binding energy of metal−N in S-VN/Co/NS-MC presents a higher binding energy. The results indicate that the sulfur atom doping possibly changes the charge density of VN species in S-VN/Co/NS-MC, thereby shifting the binding energy and promoting the reduction of oxygen molecules [17,20]. The C−C, C−N, C=O and π−π* bonds are fitted in C 1s XPS spectra of S-VN/Co/NS-MC, VN/Co/N-MC and S-VN/NS-C (Fig. S5). The C−N bond indicates the successful doping of nitrogen atoms into multi-dimensional carbon skeleton of S-VN/Co/NS-MC, VN/Co/N-MC and S-VN/NS-C. Moreover, the C−S bond is fitted in C 1s spectra of S-VN/Co/NS-MC and S-VN/NS-C, manifesting the successful doping of sulfur atoms in carbon skeleton [17]. In Co 2p XPS spectra (Fig. 2f), the prominent peaks at approximately 781.0 and 796.8 eV correspond to Co 2p 3/2 and Co 2p 1/2, respectively, accompanied by two satellite peaks at around 786.1 and 802.2 eV [32]. A characteristic peak of zero-valence Co species is observed at approximately 778.0 eV in both S-VN/Co/NS-MC and VN/Co/N-MC. Furthermore, characteristic peaks attributed to Co2+ and Co−N x components are fitted. The presence of the Co2+ peak is likely a result of the oxidation of Co due to adsorbed oxygen in the air [29]. The appearance of the Co−N x peak in the Co 2p XPS spectrum of S-VN/Co/NS-MC is attributed to the encapsulation of Co nanoparticles within the N, S-doped carbon structure [29]. 3.2 Electro-catalytical performance ORR activity of S-VN/Co/NS-MC samples synthesized with different conditions (the sulfur source, the thiourea content and the metal content) is evaluated by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) method (Fig. S6). The S-VN/Co/NS-MC displays more superior ORR performance when the sulfur source is thiourea (Fig. S6a). When the thiourea content is 0.1 g, the S-VN/Co/NS-MC exhibits the optimal ORR activity (Fig. S6b). The metal content in the S-VN/Co/NS-MC is optimized under the condition of 0.1 g thiourea. The S-VN/Co/NS-MC displays the most optimal performance when the V and Co are 0.1 and 0.1 mmol, respectively (Fig. S7). Through the condition optimization experiment, the S-VN/Co/NS-MC shows the excellent half-wave potential (E 1/2) of 0.86 V (vs. RHE) and limiting current density (J L, at 0.4 V vs. RHE) of 4.82 mA cm−2 when the content of thiourea, V, and Co sources are 0.1 g, 0.1 mmol, and 0.1 mmol, respectively. The S-VN/Co/NS-MC demonstrates an E 1/2 of 0.86 V (vs. RHE), equivalent to that of Pt/C (Fig. 3 a). The S-VN/NS-C and VN/Co/N-MC have E 1/2 values of 0.77 and 0.84 V, respectively. The J L of S-VN/Co/NS-MC, VN/Co/N-MC and S-VN/NS-C are 4.82, 4.38 and 4.13 mA cm−2 at 0.4 V (vs. RHE), respectively. The E 1/2 and J L of S-VN/Co/NS-MC are obviously higher than those of S-VN/NS-C and VN/Co/N-MC (Table S2). Furthermore, the ORR half-wave potential and limiting current density of S-VN/Co/NS-MC surpass those of S-VN/NS-C. This suggests that the introduction of Co sources, apart from facilitating the formation of multidimensional carbon skeletons, also enhances ORR activity. The Tafel slope is employed to assess the ORR kinetic differences between the synthesized samples and Pt/C. As a result, S-VN/Co/NS-MC exhibits a Tafel slope of 66.58 mV dec−1 (Fig. 3b). The Tafel slopes of VN/Co/N-MC, S-VN/NS-C, and Pt/C are 68.81, 71.96, and 74.48 mV dec−1, respectively. Conversely, S-VN/Co/NS-MC demonstrates the lowest Tafel slope. The lower Tafel slope of S-VN/Co/NS-MC suggests superior reaction kinetics [2]. The electron transfer number (n) and hydrogen peroxide yield (HO2 − %) of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC are evaluated by RRDE electrode and LSV test. The S-VN/Co/NS-MC, VN/Co/N-MC, S-VN/NS-C and Pt/C manifest larger disk currents and smaller ring currents (Fig. S8), indicating that the less hydrogen peroxide is produced during ORR. The HO2 −% of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC is less than 10% at 0.2–0.8 V during ORR process (Fig. 3c). The average n of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC is determined to be about 3.8 (Fig. 3c) at 0.2–0.8 V. The HO2 −% and average n values demonstrate the 4-electron ORR path and high catalytic efficiency on the S-VN/Co/NS-MC surface. LSV curves of S-VN/Co/NS-MC at different speeds (Fig. S9) are employed to calculate the n value based on corresponding K-L equations [34]. The n value of S-VN/Co/NS-MC is approximately 3.6, further revealing the 4-electron ORR path of S-VN/Co/NS-MC in 0.1 mol/L KOH. Moreover, the VN/Co/N-MC exhibits n and HO2 −% like S-VN/Co/NS-MC. The HO2 −% of S-VN/NS-C is higher than that of S-VN/Co/NS-MC and VN/CO/N-MC. Meanwhile, the n of S-VN/NS-C is smaller than that of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC and VN/Co/N-MC. The HO2 −% and n values indicate the weak ORR efficiency of the S-VN/NS-C. The unique multi-dimensional structure of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC and VN/Co/N-MC promotes the electronic and mass transmission, potentially resulting in higher ORR efficiency on the S-VN/Co/NS-MC [24]. The stability of S-VN/Co/NS-MC, VN/Co/N-MC, S-VN/NS-C and Pt/C catalysts during catalyzing oxygen reduction is evaluated through the long-time chronoamperometric response test. The current retention rate of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC is 93.2% after a 10-hour chronoamperometric response test (Fig. 3d). It is higher than that of VN/Co/N-MC (85.5%) S-VN/NS-C (77.7%) and Pt/C (83.7%). Furthermore, the accelerated durability test (ADT) is also utilized to evaluate the ORR stability of S-VN/Co/NS-MC [35]. After 5000 CV cycles, the decrease value of E 1/2 for S-VN/Co/NS-MC is almost zero (Fig. S10), proving the excellent stability of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC. The excellent stability of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC originates potentially from the protection of active species by a multi-dimensional carbon skeleton. The electrochemical active surface area (ECSA) of S-VN/Co/NS-MC, VN/N-C, S-VN/NS-C, VN/Co/N-MC and Pt/C are evaluated by calculated C dl values, further proving the excellent ORR performance of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC. Cyclic voltammetry curves of S-VN/Co/NS-MC, VN/Co/N-MC, S-VN/NS-C and Pt/C are tested at 1.21–1.28 V (Fig. S11). By calculation, the C dl value of S-VN/Co/NS-MC is 23.93 mF cm−2, which is higher than that of S-VN/NS-C (4.12 mF cm−2), VN/Co/N-MC (8.53 mF cm−2) and Pt/C (5.72 mF cm−2, Fig. 3e). This outcome confirms that the S-VN/Co/NS-MC exhibits a larger ECSA compared to the S-VN/NS-C and VN/Co/N-MC. The multi-dimensional structure of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC contributes to its larger ECSA and increased exposure of active sites, resulting in a further enhancement of its ORR performances. Furthermore, mass activity and specific activity are calculated based on LSV curves and C dl results (Fig. 3f). The mass activity values for the S-VN/Co/NS-MC, VN/Co/N-MC, S-VN/NS-C and 20 wt% Pt/C are determined to be 22.31, 8.91, 1.53 and 18.18 A g−1 cat, respectively. The specific activity values for the S-VN/Co/NS-MC, VN/Co/N-MC, S-VN/NS-C and 20 wt% Pt/C are calculated to be 0.53, 0.59, 0.21 and 1.80 mA cm−2 ECSA, respectively. These results provide clear evidence of the excellent ORR performance of S-VN/Co/NS-MC. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was employed to assess the resistance of the prepared samples. The S-VN/Co/NS-MC displays the smallest semicircle diameter (Fig. S12), indicating the lowest resistance and suggesting a faster charge transfer rate [36,37]. Notably, the semicircle diameter of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC is smaller than that of the VN/Co/N-MC and S-VN/NS-C samples. This unequivocally confirms that the doping of sulfur atoms and the multi-dimensional carbon structure effectively enhance the electronic conductivity of S-VN/Co/NS-MC [20]. 3.3 Theoretical calculation To confirm the impact of sulfur doping on the electronic structure of VN species and the distribution of electron spins at vanadium sites, we employed density functional theory (DFT) calculations as supporting evidence. The VN (111) plane is utilized to construct theoretical VN and sulfur-doped VN (S−VN) geometric models. Initially, the differential charge distribution and density of state for the S−VN are calculated. An evident difference in charge distribution near the sulfur-doped region of the S−VN is displayed (Fig. 4 a and Fig. S14). The sulfur center primarily exhibits electron depletion (blue area), while the surrounding vanadium sites show electron accumulation (yellow area). This represents the partial transfer of electrons from the sulfur center to vanadium sites, leading to changes in the electronic structure of the original VN and the expansion of the lattice spacing of the VN (111) plane in the S−VN. The electrons transferred from the sulfur atom to the vanadium site also potentially fill the vacant 3d orbital, enhancing the spin occupation state of vanadium sites, and consequently optimizing the σ-bonding capacity with oxygen-containing intermediates [18,22]. The total density of states (TDOS) of S−VN and VN models is depicted (Fig. 4b). Sulfur doping clearly alters the electron state distribution of VN species, inducing electron polarization in the S−VN model, particularly in the red box. Furthermore, the projected density of states (PDOS) of V 3d orbitals in VN species notably changes at the Fermi level after S doping, particularly involving spin-down electrons, indicating a potential electron rearrangement in the S−VN (Fig. 4c). Upon close examination, it becomes evident that the dz 2 orbital of V 3d exhibits significant spin polarization. The spin-down electrons partially transfer to the Fermi level in the dz 2 orbital of V 3d (Fig. 4d) [23]. The transferred electrons are probably accommodated in the unsaturated V 3dz 2 orbitals, leading to changes in the PDOS. This facilitates the regulation of the charge interaction between VN species and reactants/intermediates, accelerating dissociation efficiency, and ultimately enhancing ORR activity [23]. Therefore, compared with VN species, the more obvious electron depletion is observed between O2 molecule and the S−VN after adsorbing O2 (Fig. 4e and f, Fig. S15 and S16). The electron depletion between O2 molecule and the S−VN model benefits the dissociation of oxygen-containing intermediates. Additionally, the adsorption energy of O2 on the S−VN model is marginally higher than that of on the VN model (Fig. 4g). The enhanced ORR activity of S−VN is attributed to its higher O2 adsorption energy and superior intermediate dissociation efficiency [38,39]. During the 4-electron ORR process, a thermodynamically uphill Gibbs free energy (ΔG = 2.37 eV) is observed when *OOH dissociates into *O on the VN (Fig. 4h). The (*OOH → *O) step serves as the rate-determining step for O2 reduction on VN, leading to a substantial increase in overpotential. Conversely, the dissociation of *OOH to *O on the S−VN surface is thermodynamically favorable, signifying a spontaneous process. Ultimately, the top-to-bottom thermodynamic change in the (*OOH → *O) step results from alterations in the electronic structure due to S doping in VN. While the (*OH → H2O) process still exhibits a thermodynamic uphill tendency on S−VN, the Gibbs free energy is only 1.54 eV, considerably lower than that on VN. Consequently, the overpotential for O2 reduction on S−VN is substantially lower than that on VN. Sulfur doping modulates the efficiency of intermediate dissociation on VN species, leading to a reduction in the reaction overpotential and a lowering of the ORR barrier, thereby optimizing the ORR performance of S−VN. Based on characterization analyses and DFT calculations, the exceptional ORR performances of S-VN/Co/NS-MC are summarized in the following aspects: (1) Sulfur doping significantly modulates the electronic structure of VN and increases the lattice spacing of the VN (111) plane. Specifically, sulfur doping polarizes the spin-down V 3dz 2 electrons. Consequently, the adsorption energy of O2 on S−VN is enhanced, and the *OOH dissociation process on S−VN becomes more facile. (2) The N, S-doped multi-dimensional carbon skeleton offers additional mass transfer pathways for the O2 reduction process and optimizes the reaction kinetics of ORR on S-VN/Co/NS-MC. Furthermore, the N, S-doped multi-dimensional carbon skeleton enhances the stability of S-VN/Co/NS-MC by protecting VN species. (3) The introduction of Co sources not only facilitates the formation of multidimensional carbon skeletons but also enhances ORR activity. Moreover, the synergistic interaction among S-doped VN species, Co nanoparticles, and N, S-doped carbon skeletons collectively contributes to the outstanding ORR activity, kinetic behavior, and stability of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC catalyst. 3.4 Liquid zinc-air battery performances ZABs were assembled using S-VN/Co/NS-MC, VN/Co/N-MC, and S-VN/NS-C as cathodic catalysts, respectively. Firstly, the open-circuit potential (OCP) of the assembled ZABs is measured (Fig. 5 a). The OCP of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based ZAB is 1.49 V, slightly higher than that of Pt/C-based (1.49 V), VN/Co/N-MC-based (1.41 V), and S-VN/NS-C-based (1.41 V) ZABs. The discharge voltage of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based ZAB is notably higher than that of Pt/C-based ZAB (Fig. 5b). Correspondingly, the power density of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based ZAB is 195.7 mW cm−2, surpassing that of the Pt/C-based ZAB (142.1 mW cm−2). The power densities of VN/Co/N-MC-based and S-VN/NS-C-based ZABs are 161.6 and 74.7 mW cm−2, respectively. The higher power density of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based ZAB compared to the VN/Co/N-MC-based ZAB likely results from sulfur atom doping. The sulfur atoms doping not only improves the conductivity of S-VN/Co/NS-MC, but also weakens the electrostatic interaction between S-VN/Co/NS-MC catalyst and anodic Zn2+ ions. Then, the reaction kinetics of S-VN/Co/NS-MC surface is accelerated at the air–cathode of ZABs, thus enhancing the power density [20]. Compared with S-VN/NS-C-based ZAB, the higher power densities of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based and VN/Co/N-MC-based ZABs are because of the unique multi-dimensional morphological skeleton structure. Notably, the carbon nanotubes within the multi-dimensional skeleton increase the air transmission pathway and provide enough air pass channels for cathodic reactions of ZABs, thus displaying the greater power density [40]. Specific capacities of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based, VN/Co/N-MC-based, S-VN/NS-C-based and Pt/C-based ZABs were also evaluated at 20 mA cm−2. The S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based ZAB exhibits the specific capacity of 815.7 mA h g−1 (Fig. 5c) which is higher than that of Pt/C-based ZAB (730.7 mA h g−1). The specific capacities of VN/Co/N-MC-based and S-VN/NS-C-based ZABs are 786.9 and 707.3 mA h g−1, respectively. Accordingly, the energy densities of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based, VN/Co/N-MC-based, S-VN/NS-C-based, and Pt/C-based ZABs are 914.7, 880.6, 725.2, and 798.3 W h kg−1, respectively. The larger specific capacity and energy density of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based and VN/Co/N-MC-based ZABs confirms that the multi-dimensional skeleton structure provides more air transport pathways, so that there is enough air at the cathode of ZABs to participate in the conversion of chemical energy to electric energy. Furthermore, when sulfur atoms are doped into VN species, the adsorption/desorption process between VN species and the anodic oxidized Zn2+ ions can be improved [20]. Then, the diffusion of Zn2+ ions at zinc anode can be promoted. The power density of zinc-air batteries is thus effectively enhanced via sulfur-doped catalysts at the air-cathode [19,20]. The rate performances of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based, VN/Co/N-MC-based, S-VN/NS-C-based, and 20 wt% Pt/C-based ZABs were evaluated through varying the tested current density (multi-current steps test). The discharge voltages of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based, VN/Co/N-MC-based, S-VN/NS-C-based and 20 wt% Pt/C-based ZABs vary with the current density (Fig. 5d). The discharge voltage of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based ZAB is 1.258 V at 10 mA cm−2. When the current density is increased step by step to 50 mA cm−2, the discharge voltage of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based ZAB gradually decreases. However, when the current density gradually returns to 10 mA cm−2, the discharge voltage restores to 1.234 V. During this process, the discharge voltage of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based ZAB is maintained by about 98.1%. Similarly, the discharge voltages of VN/Co/N-MC-based ZAB are 1.251 V at the initial 10 mA cm−2 and 1.215 V at the end of the test. The corresponding discharge voltage efficiency is only maintained at 97.1%, which is lower than that of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based ZAB. The maximum discharge voltages of S-VN/NS-C-based and 20 wt% Pt/C-based ZABs are only 1.216 V at the initial 10 mA cm−2. When the tested current density is amplified and then reduced to 10 mA cm−2, the discharge voltages of S-VN/NS-C-based and 20 wt% Pt/C-based ZABs recover to 1.195 and 1.208 V, respectively. The discharge voltage efficiencies of S-VN/NS-C-based and 20 wt% Pt/C-based ZABs are about 98.2% and 99.3% during this process, respectively. The discharge voltage efficiencies of S-VN/NS-C-based and 20 wt% Pt/C-based ZABs are slightly higher than that of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based ZAB. However, the discharge voltages of S-VN/NS-C-based and 20 wt% Pt/C-based ZABs are much lower than that of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based ZAB. The higher discharge voltage and higher efficiency indicate that the S-VN/Co/NS-MC exhibits excellent rate performance in ZABs. The S-VN/Co/NS-MC possesses more excellent kinetics, more fast ion diffusion efficiency and more strong electrolyte conductivity during electrochemical reactions. These characteristics reduce the electrochemical polarization, concentration polarization and ohmic polarization of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC in ZABs, respectively [7]. Therefore, the S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based ZAB displays a higher power density and a better rate performance than that of VN/Co/N-MC-based, S-VN/NS-C-based and 20 wt% Pt/C-based ZABs. The charge-discharge cycle life tests were carried out at 5 mA cm−2 (Fig. 5e). The initial charge and discharge voltages of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based ZAB are 2.21 and 1.06 V, respectively. In this case, the corresponding round-trip efficiency of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based ZAB is 47.9%. And, the battery performance decreases slightly after a 250-hour cycle. Currently, the charge voltage is 2.20 V, and the discharge voltage is 1.01 V. The corresponding round-trip efficiency is reduced to 45.9%, which is slightly lower than the initial stage. However, after 87 h testing of Pt/C-based ZAB, the charge–discharge voltage difference increases to more than 3 V. The round-trip efficiency is lower than that of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based ZAB. In addition, the charge and discharge time of the VN/CO/N-MC-based ZAB is much lower than that of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based ZAB. However, the voltage gap between charge and discharge of the VN/Co/N-MC-based ZAB is significantly smaller than that of S-VN/NS-C-based ZAB. The voltage gap of the S-VN/NS-C-based ZAB is obviously greater than that of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC and VN/Co/N-MC-based ZABs. The cycle life of the S-VN/NS-C-based ZAB is comparable to that of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based ZAB (Table S3). Furthermore, EIS Nyquist plot manifests that S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based liquid ZAB exhibits a smaller semicircle diameter than that of Pt/C-based liquid ZAB (Fig. S17). The comparison result reveals the smaller internal resistance of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based ZAB than that of Pt/C-based ZAB [41]. 3.5 Flexible zinc-air battery performances Currently, to meet the requirements of physical deformability, there is a rapid and significant development in flexible wearable electronics, soft robotics, and related devices. As a result, flexible batteries based on hydrogels have garnered considerable attention. In this context, flexible ZABs have emerged as a focal point of research due to their compatibility with flexible energy storage, safety, and environmental considerations. Consequently, we assembled and evaluated the performance of flexible ZABs to investigate the practical applicability of S-VN/Co/NS-MC. Polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) gel mixed with KOH and Zn(CH3COO)2 is the electrolyte for flexible ZABs (Fig. 6 a). Carbon cloth (loaded with 1 mg cm−2 of the synthesized catalyst) serves as the air diffusion layer, while copper mesh functions as the current collector. Initially, the open-circuit potentials of the assembled flexible ZABs were measured, including those based on S-VN/Co/NS-MC, VN/Co/N-MC, S-VN/NS-C, and 20 wt% Pt/C. The open-circuit potential of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based flexible ZAB is 1.53 V (Fig. 6b), higher than that of VN/Coo/N-MC-based (1.49 V), S-VN/NS-C-based (1.48 V) and 20 wt% Pt/C-based flexible ZABs. This higher open-circuit potential manifests that the S-VN/Co/NS-MC can endow flexible ZAB with a higher reversibility degree. The S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based flexible ZAB exhibit the highest and smoothest discharge voltage in discharge polarization curves (short dot curves of Fig. 6c). Correspondingly, the S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based flexible ZAB can offer the largest peak power density of 39.7 mW cm−2. The peak power densities of VN/Co/N-MC-based, S-VN/NS-C-based, and 20 wt% Pt/C-based flexible ZABs are 24.5, 16.9, and 20.6 mW cm−2, respectively. The corresponding current density of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based flexible ZAB is larger than that of VN/Co/N-MC-based, S-VN/NS-C-based and 20 wt% Pt/C-based flexible ZABs at the peak power density. This result reveals that the S-VN/Co/NS-MC can make flexible ZABs generate larger power under the same current density, which is more conducive to the practical application in electrochemical energy storage devices than VN/Co/N-MC, S-VN/NS-C and 20 wt% Pt/C. The galvanostatic discharge curves at 10 mA cm−2 were employed to evaluate the specific capacity of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based, VN/Co/N-MC-based, S-VN/NS-C-based, and 20 wt% Pt/C-based flexible ZABs (Fig. 6d). The discharge voltage of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based flexible ZAB is basically maintained at 1.21 V during the test, and slightly higher than that of VN/Co/N-MC-based, S-VN/NS-C-based and 20 wt% Pt/C-based flexible ZABs. The corresponding specific capacity of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based flexible ZAB is determined as 332.8 mA h g−1 by normalizing the mass of consumed zinc cathode. This value is higher than that of VN/Co/N-MC-based (322.6 mA h g−1), S-VN/NS-C-based (160.3 mA h g−1), and 20 wt% Pt/C-based (239.4 mA h g−1) flexible ZABs. Meanwhile, the energy density of flexible ZAB is calculated through the conversion of the relationship between specific capacity with the discharge voltage. The S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based, VN/Co/N-MC-based, S-VN/NS-C-based, and 20 wt% Pt/C-based flexible ZABs can generate the energy density of 368.2, 346.6, 155.3, and 262.3 W h kg−1, respectively. This higher energy density indicates that the S-VN/Co/NS-MC can endow flexible ZAB more energy through consuming the same mass of zinc cathode than VN/Co/N-MC, S-VN/NS-C and 20 wt% Pt/C catalysts. During the practical application process, this advantage of high energy density is beneficial to reduce the fabrication cost of flexible ZABs by using the S-VN/Co/NS-MC as the air–cathode catalyst. The multi-current steps tests of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based, VN/Co/N-MC-based, S-VN/NS-C-based and 20 wt% Pt/C-based flexible ZABs were employed to evaluate the rate performances through varying the tested current density (Fig. 6e). The discharge voltage of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based flexible ZAB maintains at approximately 1.251 V at the beginning of multi-current steps test (5 mA cm−2). This value is higher than that of VN/Co/N-MC-based (1.249 V), S-VN/NS-C-based (1.222 V), and 20 wt% Pt/C-based (1.234 V) flexible ZABs. With the increase in current density, the discharge voltage of the assembled flexible ZABs presents a step-like decline. When the current density increases to 20 mA cm−2, the discharge voltage of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based flexible ZAB is slightly lower than that of VN/Co/N-MC-based flexible ZAB. However, when the current density is reduced to 5 mA cm−2, the discharge voltage of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based flexible ZAB gradually recovers and eventually remains at approximately 1.245 V. Currently, the discharge voltage is still higher than that of VN/Co/N-MC-based (1.238 V), S-VN/NS-C-based (1.221 V), and 20 wt% Pt/C-based (1.232 V) flexible ZABs. In general, the discharge voltage efficiency of the assembled flexible ZABs is higher than 99%. Remarkably, the discharge voltage of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based flexible ZAB is basically larger than that of VN/Co/N-MC-based, S-VN/NS-C-based, and 20 wt% Pt/C-based flexible ZABs throughout the multi-current steps test. This implies that the S-VN/Co/NS-MC exhibits excellent rate performance to endow the strong reversibility to flexible ZABs. To further verify the reversible and rechargeable characteristics of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC in flexible ZABs, the charge–discharge cycle curves of flexible ZABs assembled with S-VN/Co/NS-MC, VN/Co/N-MC, S-VN/NS-C and 20 wt% Pt/C were recorded at 10 mA cm−2 (Fig. 6f). At the first charge–discharge period (Fig. 6g), the discharge voltage of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based flexible ZAB is about 1.18 V, slightly lower than that of VN/Co/N-MC-based flexible ZAB (about 1.20 V), but higher than that of S-VN/NS-C-based (1.17 V) and 20 wt% Pt/C-based (1.15 V) flexible ZABs. In the first period, the round-trip efficiencies of the charge–discharge cycle for S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based, VN/Co/N-MC-based, S-VN/NS-C-based, and 20 wt% Pt/C-based flexible ZABs are 58.7%, 67.0%, 59.9%, and 61.6%, respectively. The round-trip efficiencies of charge–discharge cycle period for S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based, VN/Co/N-MC-based, S-VN/NS-C-based, and 20 wt% Pt/C-based flexible ZABs reduce to 55.6%, 57.3%, 55.8%, and 57.3% at 2.5 h, respectively. The corresponding decrease value of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based flexible ZAB is 3.1%, lower than that of VN/Co/N-MC-based (9.7%), S-VN/NS-C-based (4.1%), and 20 wt% Pt/C-based (4.3%) flexible ZABs. The charge–discharge cycle time of VN/Co/N-MC-based and S-VN/NS-C-based flexible ZABs is less than 4 h. However, the charge–discharge cycle time of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based flexible ZAB is obviously longer than that of VN/Co/N-MC-based, S-VN/NS-C-based and 20 wt% Pt/C-based flexible ZABs. The round-trip efficiency of charge–discharge cycle is 47.7% for S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based flexible ZAB (Fig. 6i). After the charge–discharge cycle for 5 h (at 10 mA cm−2), the round-trip efficiency of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based flexible ZAB only decreases by 11.0%. The excellent charge–discharge cycle stability fully proves the reversible and rechargeable characteristics of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC in flexible ZABs. The S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based flexible ZAB manifests the stable charge–discharge cycle performance at different folding angles, including the flat of 0° (inset of Fig. 6g), the bent (inset of Fig. 6h) and the folded of 90° states (inset of Fig. 6i). This phenomenon indicates that the S-VN/Co/NS-MC is promising for flexible and portable devices. Moreover, to ascertain the practical viability of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based flexible ZABs, the assembled flexible ZABs were employed to charge everyday portable electronic devices, such as the Redmi Watch 2 (M2101W1) and Huawei mobile phone (HONOR 20, YAL-AL00). The uncharged and charged states of four series-connected ZABs used to charge the Redmi Watch 2 are displayed (Fig. 6j). When the charging cable is not connected, Redmi watch 2 is in the black screen state. After the charging cable is connected, the watch screen displays that it is in a state of continuous charging. Seven series-connected ZABs were used to power essential everyday electronic devices, including the HUAWEI mobile phone. Huawei mobile phone screen is resting when the USB cable is not connected (Fig. 6k). Huawei mobile phone is successfully continuously charged after the series-wound ZABs being connected to the USB cable. This demonstrates the successful application of S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based flexible ZABs in everyday portable electronic devices, thereby contributing to the advancement of ZAB commercialization. Drawing upon the results of battery performance tests, the following deductions can be made: (1) While S-VN/NS-C lacks a multi-dimensional skeleton structure, particularly bamboo-like carbon nanotubes that offer increased gas transport paths for ZABs, the S-doped VN within S-VN/NS-C enhances ORR activity. Hence, the cycle life of the S-VN/NS-C-based ZAB matches that of the S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based ZAB. (2) The distinctive multi-dimensional skeleton structure in S-VN/Co/NS-MC and VN/Co/N-MC creates an abundance of gas transport pathways, thereby significantly improving mass transfer performance in ZABs. Consequently, S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based ZABs demonstrate optimal power density, cycle stability, and energy density close to theoretical values These findings underscore the significance of introducing a Co source during the preparation of S-VN/Co/NS-MC. Furthermore, these results demonstrate that S-VN/Co/NS-MC, known for its excellent ORR activity, also excels in practical applications of flexible ZABs. 4 Conclusions The sulfur-doped VN species anchored on multi-dimensional carbon skeleton (S-VN/Co/NS-MC) were successfully synthesized using solvothermal and in-situ doping techniques. Sulfur atom doping in VN species effectively increased the chemical valence of vanadium atoms, thereby altering the original electron spin states of vanadium atoms in S-VN/Co/NS-MC. Additionally, sulfur doping enriched the spin-down electrons in the V 3dz 2 orbitals, thereby modulating the original electronic structure of VN species. During the O2 reduction process, the electronically regulated S-VN/Co/NS-MC effectively increased the adsorption energy of O2 and decreased the dissociation energy of *OOH on the S−VN surface. Consequently, the reaction barrier for oxygen reduction at the S-VN/Co/NS-MC surface was reduced. Co nanoparticles played a crucial role in adjusting the microstructure of S-VN/Co/NS-MC. Co nanoparticles catalyzed the transformation of the carbon source into 1D bamboo-like carbon nanotubes, eventually forming a multi-dimensional carbon skeleton consisting of carbon nanotubes and nanosheets. The multi-dimensional structure exposed a greater number of active sites and enhanced the mass transfer rate. The S-VN/Co/NS-MC, displaying excellent ORR activity (E 1/2 = 0.86 V), was utilized in flexible ZABs. The series-connected S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based flexible ZABs were successfully employed to charge a smartwatch and a mobile phone. This study establishes a theoretical and experimental foundation for the development of high-performance VN-based electrocatalysts for practical applications in flexible ZABs. coredata.dc:description: Owing to the distinctive structural characteristics, vanadium nitride (VN) is highly regarded as a catalyst for oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) in zinc-air batteries (ZABs). However, VN exhibits limited intrinsic ORR activity due to the weak adsorption ability to O-containing species. Here, the S-doped VN anchored on N, S-doped multi-dimensional carbon (S-VN/Co/NS-MC) was constructed using the solvothermal and in-situ doping methods. Incorporating sulfur atoms into VN species alters the electron spin state of vanadium in the S-VN/Co/NS-MC for regulating the adsorption energy of vanadium sites to oxygen molecules. The introduced sulfur atoms polarize the V 3dz 2 electrons, shifting spin-down electrons closer to the Fermi level in the S-VN/Co/NS-MC. Consequently, the introduction of sulfur atoms into VN species enhances the adsorption energy of vanadium sites for oxygen molecules. The *OOH dissociation transitions from being unspontaneous on the VN surface to a spontaneous state on the S-doped VN surface. Then, the ORR barrier on the S-VN/Co/NS-MC surface is reduced. The S-VN/Co/NS-MC demonstrates a higher half-wave potential and limiting current density compared to the VN/Co/N-MC. The S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based liquid ZABs display a power density of 195.7 mW cm−2, a specific capacity of 815.7 mA h g−1, and a cycling stability exceeding 250 h. The S-VN/Co/NS-MC-based flexible ZABs are successfully employed to charge both a smart watch and a mobile phone. This approach holds promise for advancing the commercial utilization of VN-based catalysts in ZABs.
